question: Question_08
statement:
Consider the linear differential equation

\begin{align*}
x'(t) &= 3x(t) + 4y(t)\\
y'(t) &= 3x(t) + 2y(t)\\
\end{align*}

with the initial conditions $\displaystyle x(0) = 6$,
$\displaystyle y(0) = 1$. Find the solution
$\displaystyle u(t) = (x(t),y(t))^{T}$ and determine the stability of
the differential equation.
sols:
To begin with we rewrite the system in matrix form:

\[\begin{bmatrix}
x'(t) \\ y'(t)
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
3 & 4 \\ 3 & 2
\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}
x(t) \\ y(t)
\end{bmatrix}\]

and call this matrix \emph{A}. We need the eigenvalues of \emph{A} and
hence find the zeros of the characteristic polynomials

\begin{align*}
\det(A-\lambda I) &= \det\left(\begin{bmatrix}
3-\lambda & 4 \\ 3 & 2-\lambda
\end{bmatrix}\right) \\
&= (3-\lambda)(2-\lambda)-12 \\
&= \lambda^2 - 5\lambda -6 \\
&= (\lambda-6)(\lambda+1)
\end{align*}

We see that \emph{λ\textsubscript{1} = 6} and \emph{λ\textsubscript{2} =
-1}.

Next, we calculate corresponding eigenvectors. For
\emph{λ\textsubscript{1} = 6} we find the eigenvectors in the null space
of $\begin{bmatrix}
-3 & 4 \\ 3 & -4
\end{bmatrix}$ e.g. $v_1 = \begin{bmatrix}
4 \\ 3
\end{bmatrix}$. Similarly, for \emph{λ\textsubscript{2} = -1} we find
the eigenvectors in the null space of $\begin{bmatrix}
4 & 4 \\ 3 & 3
\end{bmatrix}$ e.g. $v_2 = \begin{bmatrix}
1 \\ -1
\end{bmatrix}$. Hence, the general solution of the linear differential
equation is given by

\[\begin{bmatrix}
x(t) \\ y(t)
\end{bmatrix} = c_1 \begin{bmatrix}
4 \\ 3
\end{bmatrix} e^{6t} + c_2 \begin{bmatrix}
1 \\ -1
\end{bmatrix} e^{-t}\]

To find the values of the constants \emph{c\textsubscript{1}} and
\emph{c\textsubscript{2}} we plug in the values at the initial condition
\emph{t = 0}:

\begin{align*}
x(0) &= 6 &= 4c_1 + c_2 \\
y(0) &= 1 &= 3c_1 - c_2
\end{align*} which has the solution \emph{c\textsubscript{1} = 1},
\emph{c\textsubscript{2} = 2}. Therefore, the full solution of the
linear differential equation with the given initial conditions is

\[u(t) = \begin{bmatrix}
x(t) \\ y(t)
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
4 \\ 3
\end{bmatrix} e^{6t} + \begin{bmatrix}
2 \\ -2
\end{bmatrix} e^{-t}\]

Finally, since one of the eigenvalues is positive, the differential
equation is unstable.
hints:
Start by writing the differential equation in matrix form \emph{u' =
Au}.

If the eigenvalues of the corresponding matrix \emph{A} are distinct,
then the general solution of the linear differential equation is given
by

\[\displaystyle u(t) = c_1 v_1 e^{\lambda_1 t} + c_2 v_2 e^{\lambda_2 t}\]

where \emph{v\textsubscript{1}} and \emph{v\textsubscript{2}} are
eigenvectors corresponding to the eigenvalues \emph{λ\textsubscript{1}}
and \emph{λ\textsubscript{2}}, respectively, and
\emph{c\textsubscript{1}, c\textsubscript{2}} are constants.

Next, use the initial condition to solve for the constants
\emph{c\textsubscript{1}} and \emph{c\textsubscript{2}}.

Finally, the stability is determined by the sign of the (real part of
the) eigenvalues.
